title: 111_hr2058
content: The Act titled "Post-Deployment Health Assessment Act of 2009" mandates mental health screenings for members of the armed forces deployed in connection with a contingency operation. The "Post-Deployment Health Assessment Act of 2009" requires the Secretary of Defense to provide in-person mental health screenings for deployed Armed Forces members within specific timeframes before and after deployment in connection with a contingency operation. The "Post-Deployment Health Assessment Act of 2009" mandates mental health screenings for deployed Armed Forces members to identify PTSD, suicidal tendencies, and other behavioral health issues. Members not exposed to combat stress may be excluded from the screenings. The "Post-Deployment Health Assessment Act of 2009" mandates mental health screenings for deployed Armed Forces members to identify PTSD, suicidal tendencies, and other behavioral health issues. Screenings are to be conducted by trained personnel and include in-person dialogues to achieve the screening's purpose. The Secretary may consider existing health assessments and screenings for Armed Forces members as meeting mental health screening requirements under the Act. No mental health screenings are required after discharge. The Secretary of Defense must share relevant information with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. The Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs may share confidential mental health screening information for continuity of care during the transition from Department of Defense to Department of Veterans Affairs. Sharing protocols must be jointly established. The Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs may share mental health screening information for continuity of care. Protocols must be consistent with specific laws and definitions. Reports to Congress are required on the guidance and its implementation. After one year, the Secretary must report to Congress on the military departments' implementation of mental health screenings, assessing their effectiveness in achieving the specified purpose.
